pageSummary: 100km Bike Ride because the work they do is vital to a patient with cancer
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page which I have created to raise money for Macmillan on behalf of my beloved Nanaji Ajaib Singh Sidhu. 

My Nanaji. Aged 70 years. Married for 50. Father for 48 and Grandfather for 29. 

When our beautiful Dad learned that his cancer had sadly returned and that there was nothing more that the doctors could do to prolong his life, he remained incredibly strong, positive and resilient. As his condition progressively got worse, he still remained independent and determined to fight until the end. He continued to show us love, made us laugh and continued to be present as much as he could. This bought us so much joy whilst also giving us the strength and resilience just like he had. He showed us that we could get through this and we all remained positive around him as well. He smiled and participated until the very end. 

We’re so proud of you dad that you fought as much as you could. We will miss you very much. Our hearts are broken and although it is hard to imagine a world without you in it, I am so proud to say that we are all here cherishing your memories, continuing to love you and remaining strong just like you were.

In honour of you, I will be doing a 100km bike ride (I have also managed to recruit Sabinder Mahal and Amenah Lakhanpal who have happily offered their support) within the next 4 weeks to raise money for Macmillan so that we can work to make a vital difference to people affected by cancer. The work that they do is crucial and imperative to the families of cancer patients. Thank you for all that you do.

Please join me in supporting their incredible work and to become even better by donating through JustGiving which is simple, fast and totally secure. story:
Friday 2nd October 2020 the day our whole world came crashing down.

We had our 20 week scan and we were told it looks like baby has an abnormality on his spine. We got sent up to the Royal Infirmary straight away to be seen by doctors and midwifes. This is where the dreaded news was confirmed. Our precious baby has myelomeningocele, the most severe type of Spina Bifida which is not curable😢. We were told our baby will be paralysed from the waist down and will never be able to walk or have full function of his bladder and bowels and have possible brain damage.

We were given 2 choices from the hospital, to terminate the pregnancy or carry on knowing he’s going to have a severe disability. We were left over the weekend to do research and make the hardest and most heartbreaking decision of our entire life’s.

During research we found an article about Great Ormond Street Children’s Hospital in London performing the first U.K. surgery in the womb for a baby with Spina Bifida in 2018. This is quite a complex surgery which involves opening up the mothers stomach and womb, exposing the Spina Bifida but keeping baby in the sac and not delivering him, closing the hole in the spine, putting baby back inside the womb safely and stitching mum back up. This was something we were keen to find out more about and this meant we now possibly had a 3rd choice.

When we returned to the hospital on Monday for our next appointment we asked about this surgery. We spoke with Midwifes, Doctors, Neurosurgeons and teams that specialise in children with Spina Bifida. They gave us all the information we needed. At this stage baby is still able to move and kick his legs around in the womb so one of the major benefits of this surgery is although it won’t be able to cure the Spina Bifida as nothing can, it can prevent any further damage being done from now until he is born. Which means preserving the movement he has in his legs at the minute and this gives him a greater chance of being able to walk. As this was something we were interested in a doctor phoned the surgeons at Great Ormond Street to find out if I met the criteria to be considered for the surgery... which I did!

After countless hospital, midwife, specialists and telephone appointments to gather as much information, test results and medical history etc. We finally got all our results back which came back as good as they possibly can be. There’s no sign of him having any brain damage.

Ross and I as a couple have decided we want to give our precious boy the best chance he deserves in life. So any day now I can receive a phone call to say they’re going ahead with this surgery. One major thing is we’re not sure whether this surgery is going to take place in London or Belgium. Any donations towards Great Ormond Street Children’s Charity would be greatly appreciated from the both of us as the only way this surgery can be offered on the NHS is if they can rely on donations from the public towards this charity. Any shares of our story are also greatly appreciated to raise awareness of this surgery as many people don’t know this 3rd choice exists. Thank You.💫💙💛

*We have 2 donation pages as the one on Facebook only lets us share it on Facebook so we had to make a second one that we could share on all social media so if you’ve donated to one then you don’t have to donate to the other*

story:
Welcome Mr Pudding's Festive Selfie Challenge!

On a Saturday morning in early December, for the last 39 years, London’s iconic Covent Garden has been filled with an air of anticipation as runners wearing brightly coloured fancy dress costumes line up, and get ready to race around a unique fun filled festive obstacle course and raise vital funds for Cancer Research UK, all whilst balancing a Christmas Pudding on a tray – not such an easy task we can assure you!

This year would have been The Great Christmas Pudding Race’s 40th event. Over the last four decades, with the help of our amazing teams, sponsors and supporters, our volunteer committee has raised an incredible £1.6 million for Cancer Research UK. Due to COVID-19, we have had to postpone our milestone race until December 2021, leaving a gap of at least £25,000 that would have been raised for lifesaving research this year. These funds are needed now more than ever by Cancer Research UK who have seen their fundraising income drop by 30%, in part due to the cancellation of events such as The Great Christmas Pudding Race.

Because of this, our committee is even more determined to ensure we contribute towards the vital money needed by Cancer Research UK this year and we are calling on you to support us by getting involved and taking part in our very first…...Mr Pudding's Festive Selfie Challenge!

All you need to do is:
1. Donate £6 to Cancer Research UK
2. Post your most festive selfie on social media with our Mr Pudding's stickers. filters or frames and tag @MrXmasPudding and use #MrPudding&Me
3. Nominate 6 of your friends to do the same!

Why £6 and why nominate 6 friends, we hear you ask? This is of course Christmas pudding related! Traditionally, a silver sixpence was always hidden in the Christmas pudding mix AND... to compete in the The Great Christmas Pudding Race, you need a team of 6.

We are aiming to raise as much money as possible from Mr Pudding's Festive Selfie Challenge for a cause which is close to all our hearts. If you are able to donate more than £6, that would be fantastic but any donation is truly appreciated in this exceptionally challenging year. Please get involved by sharing our campaign and helping us to spread the word as far as possible.

Don’t forget to check out our Facebook @mrpudding and Instagram @mrxmaspudding accounts each week as well as our website xmaspuddingrace.org.uk for a compilation of the best Mr Pudding selfies!

Thank you for your much needed support :)

TOGETHER WE CAN BEAT CANCER!

story:
I will be walking the full 78km of the 12ks of Christmas challenge in 12 hours. 

Over the past year, dying has become a front-of-mind issue for us all. The pandemic and our ageing population means its never been more pressing to make sure we have the right care and support in place to be able to protect and cherish each other as we reach the final months, weeks, days and hours of our lives.         

Every day and night, our Marie Curie nurses and frontline staff, continue providing vital support to dying people and their families in their own homes.

There has never been more need for Marie Curie. Caring for people in their own homes relieves the pressure off our hospitals when beds are needed more than ever.    

But all of this will take money. We rely heavily on the generosity of the public to help deliver our care, but as events and activities are postponed or cancelled, we face a devastating loss to our income. 

Whilst our frontline teams are working day and night to meet growing need, Marie Curie needs to raise £13,888 every hour, 24 hours a day.

This year, every day from the 1st to 12th of December I will be walking on my hour lunch break to help raise money for people living with a terminal illness. I’m hoping to complete the full 78km in 12 hours.  If it takes me longer than this, I will be donating £1 for every extra minute!

The impact of the coronavirus will be felt for a long time, particularly among families grieving the loss of a loved one. We have updated information and support on our website if a family member or friend is living with terminal illness, or if you have a terminal illness yourself, you may be worried about coronavirus. ww.mariecurie.org.uk or please call our support line.

We’re here for you on 0800 090 2309

story:
THE R.N.L.I. “FISH” at Robin Hood's Bay

Sitting on the tide washed slipway at Robin Hood's Bay since 1886 is a 17 stone cast iron Codfish, which has been collecting pennies and pounds all these years for the RNLI Lifeboat Charity. It is believed to be one of the oldest lifeboat collecting boxes in the world, and is also the smallest listed structure in the UK!

“The  Fish” was presented by Captain Isaac Mills, a 36 year old Master
Mariner, and local shipowner, only five years after the famous “Visiter”
rescue, and four years after the village's new lifeboat station had opened, a time when there was tremendous loss of life due to shipwreck along the Yorkshire coast.

The old fishermen would tell children to “Put a penny in itsmouth and it’ll flick its tail !”. When the inevitable happened and it didn’t flick its tail, the reply was always “Weh try again, maybe's it was t’quick f’ya”

The popular photograph shows “The  Fish” in the early 1900`s with Will Storm, a former lifeboat coxwain, and a young Gladys Dixon. Since then, generations of children visiting Robin Hood's Bay have been photographed “Feeding the Fish”.  

During 2020 we haven't been able to do our usual fundraising for the RNLI but the Yorkshire lifeboats have been busier than ever this year and we want to continue raising funds for the volunteer crews who help save lives at sea.  Can you donate to our Just Giving page and help to virtually fill the fish?!  Every little bit is appreciated.  Thank you.



Thank you for visiting my JustGiving page. RNLI lifeboats in Yorkshire and the North East protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. Your donation to this page will help support the running of lifeboat stations in Yorkshire and the North East.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. 

The fight against COVID-19 brings into sharp relief the importance of everything UNICEF does as an organization – not only to support children and young people, but to help their communities build stronger health, education, protection, nutrition, and water and sanitation system for the future. Among the challenges to achieving the UNICEF Sustainable Development Goals for children are the unprecedented levels of humanitarian crises, including the global pandemic of COVID-19, and a climate shaped by limited predictable resources.
This year, the UNICEF ESCP- London society will focus on Nepal. At present, Nepal is the third poorest among 58 countries in Asia with the sixth lowest human development ranking. Children are over-represented among the poor with 31% of children under 18 years of age living in poverty. 

Some facts that persist despite the global pandemic:
Health - Quality of water is poor with 71% of all water sources and 91% of those used by the poorest quintile contaminated with Escherichia coli bacteria, beyond the World Health Organization standard.
Nutrition - 10% of children under five years of age don’t meet the minimum nutrition requirements.
Education and Safety - Issues that persist in education include poor quality and inequity in access, gender, socioeconomic and ethnic differences. Only a few schools meet the child-friendly school standards and only 11% of school buildings are earthquake-resistant. 

What, as a society we, with UNICEF, plan to achive
Target 1 Health: By 2022, children and women of reproductive age have improved and equitable access to and use of high-impact quality health interventions and improved healthy behaviors.
Target 2 Nutrition: By 2022, children and women of reproductive age have improved and equitable access to and use of adequate nutritious diets and improved nutritional behavior and care practices
Target 3 Education and Safety: By 2022, all children, especially the most disadvantaged, benefit from improved access to, participation in and learning outcomes in pre-primary and basic education within inclusive, safe and protective environments. Children have improved protection from all forms of violence, abuse and exploitation.
